Output: The two main knowledge gaps addressed in the study regarding spectral diversity are improving species identification through different spectral band combinations and incorporating them within canopy texture parameterizations, and mapping spectral diversity (SD) and richness and studying their relations with environmental and human-derived factors along the Mediterranean to semi-arid climatic gradient.

instruction: What methodology was used to classify woody species and what was the overall accuracy achieved?
Output: The methodology used to classify woody species was a machine learning support vector machine (SVM) classification. The SVM classification was trained using a hyperspectral image acquired by an airborne flight of AISA-FENIX. The image had a spectral range of 380-2500 nm and consisted of 420 bands. The SVM classification achieved an overall accuracy of 86.1%.

instruction: How did the researchers aim to improve the accuracy of woody species classification and estimate local species richness in response to environmental and human-derived factors?
Output:
The researchers aimed to improve the accuracy of woody species classification by developing a comprehensive methodology based on spectral diversity. They used a hyperspectral image acquired using an airborne flight of AISA-FENIX, which captured 420 bands ranging from 380 to 2500 nm. They surveyed the dominant species in the study area, totaling 247 trees and shrubs, to train a machine learning support vector machine (SVM) classification for species distribution mapping. This classification yielded an overall accuracy of 86.1%.

To further improve the accuracy of woody species classification, the researchers developed a feature extraction and selection methodology. They combined principal component analysis and neighborhood component analysis techniques to identify 33 spectral diagnostic bands out of the 330 spectral bands. By using these 33 spectral bands, the classification accuracy decreased slightly to 84.2%. However, when texture information was added, the classification accuracy improved by about 7.1% for the seven large crown species, reaching 93.3%.

instruction: Can the developed methodology based on spectral diversity be used to accurately estimate woody species distribution and richness along a Mediterranean to semi-arid climatic gradient?
Output: Yes, the developed methodology based on spectral diversity can be used to accurately estimate woody species distribution and richness along a Mediterranean to semi-arid climatic gradient. The study utilized a hyperspectral image and machine learning techniques to classify and map the distribution of woody species with an overall accuracy of 86.1%. Additionally, a feature extraction and selection methodology was developed to identify spectral diagnostic bands, further improving the classification accuracy. The methodology also allowed for the calculation of local species richness using the alpha diversity index, which was found to be sensitive to environmental factors such as climate, substrate, topography, and land cover. The approach presented in the study significantly improves the estimation of woody species distribution and diversity in areas characterized by high spatial heterogeneity along steep climatic gradients.
